questions.text: A 26-year-old woman posted for LSCS under spinal anesthesia was given 2.8ml of 0.5% heavy bupivacaine in the subarachnoid space. Her BP fell from 120/80 mm Hg to 70/40 mm Hg. What should be the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IV Phenylephrine and Fluids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Noradrenaline is a potent vasoconstrictor and can be used to treat hypotension . However, it may not be the first choice in the obstetric population due to its strong alpha-adrenergic effects , which can decrease uterine blood flow .
  • • Option A.
  • • Noradrenaline
  • • potent vasoconstrictor
  • • treat hypotension
  • • strong alpha-adrenergic effects
  • • decrease uterine blood flow
  • • Option B. Mephentermine is a sympathomimetic agent used to treat hypotension , particularly in obstetric anesthesia , but it is less commonly used than phenylephrine and may cause tachycardia .

  • • treat hypotension
  • • obstetric anesthesia
  • • tachycardia
  • • Option C. Ephedrine has both alpha and beta-adrenergic effects and can increase blood pressure . It was previously widely used in obstetric anesthesia but has fallen out of favor due to concerns about fetal acidosis .

questions.text: Most preferred muscle relaxant in obstetric anaesthesia is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Succinylcholine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Atracurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant with an intermediate duration of action . It is broken down by the body through Hofmann elimination and ester hydrolysis , which can be useful in patients with organ dysfunction . However, it is not the preferred muscle relaxant in emergency obstetric surgeries due to its slower onset compared to succinylcholine.

It is the preferred alternative to succinylcholine when succinylcholine is contraindicated , such as in patients with a history of malignant hyperthermia or those with atypical plasma cholinesterase .

questions.text: Maintenance fluid in children has been calculated as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4-2-1 formula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Maintenance requirements for pediatric patients can be determined by the “4:2:1 rule” or the Holliday Segar formula : 4 mL/kg/h for the first 10 kg of weight , 2 mL/kg/h for the second 10 kg , and 1 mL/kg/h for each remaining kilogram . The choice of maintenance fluid remains controversial. A solution such as Dextrose 5% and 1⁄2 Normal saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium chloride provides adequate dextrose and electrolytes at these maintenance infusion rates.
